explanation: The report is correct. MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 requires that uses of string.h functions (strlen, memcpy, etc.) must not cause accesses beyond the bounds of the referenced objects. The code as written can violate that requirement: • Integer overflow when computing the allocation size: old_len + size + 1 is not checked for wrap-around. If size > SIZE_MAX - old_len - 1 the sum wraps, malloc is called with a much smaller value, and the subsequent memcpy(buf, *ret, old_len) (and memcpy(&buf[old_len], data, size)) can write beyond the destination buffer. This is exactly an out‑of‑bounds access caused by the use of memcpy. • strlen(*ret) could also read out of bounds if *ret is not a properly NUL‑terminated string; while in the shown code do_append sets the NUL terminator, that guarantee only holds if every writer keeps the invariant — otherwise strlen could read past the object. Because of the unchecked addition and the resulting possible buffer underrun/overrun, the use of memcpy/strlen can indeed lead to accesses beyond object bounds, violating Rule 21.17. Recommended fixes include checking for size_t overflow before calling malloc (e.g. if (size > SIZE_MAX - old_len - 1) handle error), and ensuring the retained string is always NUL‑terminated by contract.
